column2: A week after the tea at the manse Diana Barry gave a party.
column3: A week after the tea at the manse Diana Barry gave a party.

column2: Small and select, Anne assured Marilla.
column3: Small and select, Anne assured Marilla.

column2: Just the girls in our class.
column3: Just the girls in our class.

column2: They had a very good time and nothing untoward happened until after tea, when they found themselves in the Barry garden, a little tired of all their games and ripe for any enticing form of mischief which might present itself.
column3: They had a very good time and nothing untoward happened until after tea, when they found themselves in the Barry garden, a little tired of all their games and ripe for any enticing form of mischief which might present itself.

column2: It had begun among the boys, but soon spread to the girls, and all the silly things that were done in Avonlea that summer because the doers thereof were "dared" to do them would fill a book by themselves.
column3: It had begun among the boys, but soon spread to the girls, and all the silly things that were done in Avonlea that summer because the doers thereof were "dared" to do them would fill a book by themselves.

column2: First of all Carrie Sloane dared Ruby Gillis to climb to a certain point in the huge old willow tree before the front door; which Ruby Gillis, albeit in mortal dread of the fat green caterpillars with which said tree was infested and with the fear of her mother before her eyes if she should tear her new muslin dress, nimbly did, to the discomfiture of the aforesaid Carrie Sloane.
column3: First of all Carrie Sloane dared Ruby Gillis to climb to a certain point in the huge old willow tree before the front door; which Ruby Gillis, albeit in mortal dread of the fat green caterpillars with which said tree was infested and with the fear of her mother before her eyes if she should tear her new muslin dress, nimbly did, to the discomfiture of the aforesaid Carrie Sloane.

column2: But Josie Pye, if deficient in some qualities that make for popularity, had at least a natural and inborn gift, duly cultivated, for walking board fences.
column3: But Josie Pye, if deficient in some qualities that make for popularity, had at least a natural and inborn gift, duly cultivated, for walking board fences.

column2: Josie walked the Barry fence with an airy unconcern which seemed to imply that a little thing like that wasn't worth a "dare." Reluctant admiration greeted her exploit, for most of the other girls could appreciate it, having suffered many things themselves in their efforts to walk fences.
column3: Josie walked the Barry fence with an airy unconcern which seemed to imply that a little thing like that wasn't worth a "dare." Reluctant admiration greeted her exploit, for most of the other girls could appreciate it, having suffered many things themselves in their efforts to walk fences.

column2: Josie descended from her perch, flushed with victory, and darted a defiant glance at Anne.
column3: Josie descended from her perch, flushed with victory, and darted a defiant glance at Anne.

column2: I don't think it's such a very wonderful thing to walk a little, low, board fence, she said.
column3: I don't think it's such a very wonderful thing to walk a little, low, board fence, she said.

column2: I don't believe it, said Josie flatly.
column3: I don't believe it, said Josie flatly.

column2: I don't believe anybody could walk a ridgepole.	I don't believe anybody could walk a ridgepole.
YOU couldn't, anyhow."
column3: YOU couldn't, anyhow."

column2: Couldn't I? cried Anne rashly.
column3: Couldn't I? cried Anne rashly.

column2: Then I dare you to do it, said Josie defiantly.
column3: Then I dare you to do it, said Josie defiantly.

column2: I dare you to climb up there and walk the ridgepole of Mr. Barry's kitchen roof.
column3: I dare you to climb up there and walk the ridgepole of mr Barry's kitchen roof.

column2: All the fifth-class girls said, "Oh!" partly in excitement, partly in dismay.
column3: All the fifth class girls said, "Oh!" partly in excitement, partly in dismay.

column2: You'll fall off and be killed.	You'll fall off and be killed.
Never mind Josie Pye.
column3: Never mind Josie Pye.

column2: I shall walk that ridgepole, Diana, or perish in the attempt.	I shall walk that ridgepole, Diana, or perish in the attempt.
If I am killed you are to have my pearl bead ring."
column3: If I am killed you are to have my pearl bead ring."

column2: Nevertheless, she managed to take several steps before the catastrophe came.
column3: Nevertheless, she managed to take several steps before the catastrophe came.

column2: Then she swayed, lost her balance, stumbled, staggered, and fell, sliding down over the sun-baked roof and crashing off it through the tangle of Virginia creeper beneath--all before the dismayed circle below could give a simultaneous, terrified shriek.
column3: Then she swayed, lost her balance, stumbled, staggered, and fell, sliding down over the sun baked roof and crashing off it through the tangle of Virginia creeper beneath-all before the dismayed circle below could give a simultaneous, terrified shriek.

column2: Fortunately she fell on the other side, where the roof extended down over the porch so nearly to the ground that a fall therefrom was a much less serious thing.
column3: Fortunately she fell on the other side, where the roof extended down over the porch so nearly to the ground that a fall therefrom was a much less serious thing.

column2: Oh, Anne, dear Anne, speak just one word to me and tell me if you're killed.
column3: Oh, Anne, dear Anne, speak just one word to me and tell me if you're killed.

column2: Where? sobbed Carrie Sloane.
column3: Where? sobbed Carrie Sloane.

column2: Oh, where, Anne? Before Anne could answer Mrs. Barry appeared on the scene.
column3: Oh, where, Anne? Before Anne could answer mrs Barry appeared on the scene.

column2: What's the matter?	What's the matter?
My ankle, gasped Anne.
column3: My ankle, gasped Anne.

column2: Oh, Diana, please find your father and ask him to take me home.	Oh, Diana, please find your father and ask him to take me home.
I know I can never walk there.
column3: I know I can never walk there.

column2: Marilla was out in the orchard picking a panful of summer apples when she saw Mr. Barry coming over the log bridge and up the slope, with Mrs. Barry beside him and a whole procession of little girls trailing after him.
column3: Marilla was out in the orchard picking a panful of summer apples when she saw mr Barry coming over the log bridge and up the slope, with mrs Barry beside him and a whole procession of little girls trailing after him.

column2: At that moment Marilla had a revelation.
column3: At that moment Marilla had a revelation.

column2: In the sudden stab of fear that pierced her very heart she realized what Anne had come to mean to her. She would have admitted that she liked Anne--nay, that she was very fond of Anne.
column3: In the sudden stab of fear that pierced her very heart she realized what Anne had come to mean to her. She would have admitted that she liked Anne-nay, that she was very fond of Anne.

column2: Mr. Barry, what has happened to her? she gasped, more white and shaken than the self-contained, sensible Marilla had been for many years.
column3: mr Barry, what has happened to her? she gasped, more white and shaken than the self-contained, sensible Marilla had been for many years.

column2: Don't be very frightened, Marilla.	Don't be very frightened, Marilla.
I was walking the ridgepole and I fell off.
column3: I was walking the ridgepole and I fell off.

column2: I expect I have sprained my ankle.
column3: I expect I have sprained my ankle.

column2: Let us look on the bright side of things."
column3: Let us look on the bright side of things."

column2: Mercy me, the child has gone and fainted!"
column3: Mercy me, the child has gone and fainted!"

column2: It was quite true.
column3: It was quite true.

column2: Matthew, hastily summoned from the harvest field, was straightway dispatched for the doctor, who in due time came, to discover that the injury was more serious than they had supposed.
column3: matthew, hastily summoned from the harvest field, was straightway dispatched for the doctor, who in due time came, to discover that the injury was more serious than they had supposed.

column2: That night, when Marilla went up to the east gable, where a white-faced girl was lying, a plaintive voice greeted her from the bed.
column3: That night, when Marilla went up to the east gable, where a white faced girl was lying, a plaintive voice greeted her from the bed.

column2: It was your own fault, said Marilla, twitching down the blind and lighting a lamp.
column3: It was your own fault, said Marilla, twitching down the blind and lighting a lamp.

column2: And that is just why you should be sorry for me, said Anne, "because the thought that it is all my own fault is what makes it so hard.
column3: And that is just why you should be sorry for me, said Anne, "because the thought that it is all my own fault is what makes it so hard.

column2: If I could blame it on anybody I would feel so much better.
column3: If I could blame it on anybody I would feel so much better.

column2: But what would you have done, Marilla, if you had been dared to walk a ridgepole?"
column3: But what would you have done, Marilla, if you had been dared to walk a ridgepole?"

column2: I'd have stayed on good firm ground and let them dare away.	I'd have stayed on good firm ground and let them dare away.
Such absurdity!" said Marilla.
column3: Such absurdity!" said Marilla.

column2: I haven't.
column3: I haven't.

column2: I just felt that I couldn't bear Josie Pye's scorn.
column3: I just felt that I couldn't bear Josie Pye's scorn.

column2: It's not a bit nice to faint, after all. And the doctor hurt me dreadfully when he was setting my ankle.
column3: It's not a bit nice to faint, after all. And the doctor hurt me dreadfully when he was setting my ankle.

column2: I won't be able to go around for six or seven weeks and I'll miss the new lady teacher.
column3: I won't be able to go around for six or seven weeks and I'll miss the new lady teacher.

column2: She won't be new any more by the time I'm able to go to school. And Gil--everybody will get ahead of me in class.
column3: She won't be new any more by the time I'm able to go to school. And Gil-everybody will get ahead of me in class.

column2: Oh, I am an afflicted mortal.
column3: Oh, I am an afflicted mortal.

column2: But I'll try to bear it all bravely if only you won't be cross with me, Marilla."
column3: But I'll try to bear it all bravely if only you won't be cross with me, Marilla."

column2: There, there, I'm not cross, said Marilla.
column3: There, there, I'm not cross, said Marilla.

column2: You're an unlucky child, there's no doubt about that; but as you say, you'll have the suffering of it.	You're an unlucky child, there's no doubt about that; but as you say, you'll have the suffering of it.
Here now, try and eat some supper."
column3: Here now, try and eat some supper."

column2: Isn't it fortunate I've got such an imagination? said Anne.
column3: Isn't it fortunate I've got such an imagination? said Anne.

column2: It will help me through splendidly, I expect.	It will help me through splendidly, I expect.
What do people who haven't any imagination do when they break their bones, do you suppose, Marilla?"
column3: What do people who haven't any imagination do when they break their bones, do you suppose, Marilla?"

column2: But she was not solely dependent on it.
column3: But she was not solely dependent on it.

column2: She had many visitors and not a day passed without one or more of the schoolgirls dropping in to bring her flowers and books and tell her all the happenings in the juvenile world of Avonlea.
column3: She had many visitors and not a day passed without one or more of the schoolgirls dropping in to bring her flowers and books and tell her all the happenings in the juvenile world of Avonlea.

column2: Why, even Superintendent Bell came to see me, and he's really a very fine man.
column3: Why, even Superintendent Bell came to see me, and he's really a very fine man.

column2: Not a kindred spirit, of course; but still I like him and I'm awfully sorry I ever criticized his prayers.
column3: Not a kindred spirit, of course; but still I like him and I'm awfully sorry I ever criticized his prayers.

column2: He could get over that if he'd take a little trouble.
column3: He could get over that if he'd take a little trouble.

column2: I gave him a good broad hint.
column3: I gave him a good broad hint.

column2: He told me all about the time he broke his ankle when he was a boy.
column3: He told me all about the time he broke his ankle when he was a boy.

column2: When I try to imagine him as a boy I see him with gray whiskers and spectacles, just as he looks in Sunday school, only small.
column3: When I try to imagine him as a boy I see him with gray whiskers and spectacles, just as he looks in Sunday school, only small.

column2: Isn't that something to be proud of, Marilla?
column3: Isn't that something to be proud of, Marilla?

column2: When a minister's wife has so many claims on her time!
column3: When a minister's wife has so many claims on her time!

column2: She never tells you it's your own fault and she hopes you'll be a better girl on account of it.
column3: She never tells you it's your own fault and she hopes you'll be a better girl on account of it.

column2: Even Josie Pye came to see me.
column3: Even Josie Pye came to see me.

column2: I received her as politely as I could, because I think she was sorry she dared me to walk a ridgepole.
column3: I received her as politely as I could, because I think she was sorry she dared me to walk a ridgepole.

column2: Diana has been a faithful friend.
column3: Diana has been a faithful friend.

column2: She's been over every day to cheer my lonely pillow.
column3: She's been over every day to cheer my lonely pillow.

column2: The girls all think she is perfectly sweet.
column3: The girls all think she is perfectly sweet.

column2: Oh, it's just glorious to think of it.
column3: Oh, it's just glorious to think of it.

column2: And the Friday afternoons they don't have recitations Miss Stacy takes them all to the woods for a 'field' day and they study ferns and flowers and birds.
column3: And the Friday afternoons they don't have recitations Miss Stacy takes them all to the woods for a 'field' day and they study ferns and flowers and birds.
